items.synopsis: It's a long way from anywhere, but Thargomindah in outback Queensland — population 243 — goes to extraordinary lengths to ensure residents don't desert the town.

title.children: Welcome to the outback town where residents are renting to buy their homes

image.altText: Trump in front of a US flag, raising his fist

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump is indicted on criminal charges. Follow live.

title.children: Trump indicted by grand jury on four charges over 2020 election

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In an interview on CNN a short time ago, Donald Trump's attorney John Lauro says the indictment is an attempt to "censor free speech". He says Mr Trump was told by people after the 2020 presidential election "that there were problems" with it and "he also saw in real time that the rules were changing without the state legislatures weighing in". Mr Lauro said his client was relying on the advice of an attorney, John Eastman. Mr Eastman was the architect of a legal strategy aimed at keeping Mr Trump in power.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump lawyer calls indictment an 'attack on free speech and political advocacy'

children.content: In an interview on CNN a short time ago, Donald Trump's attorney
John Lauro
says the indictment is an attempt to "censor free speech".

He says Mr Trump was told by people after the 2020 presidential election "that there were problems" with it and "he also saw in real time that the rules were changing without the state legislatures weighing in".
Mr Lauro said his client was relying on the advice of an attorney, John Eastman. Mr Eastman was the architect of a legal strategy aimed at keeping Mr Trump in power.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Taking to social media, the former vice-president said the indictment "serves as an important reminder [that] anyone who puts himself over the Constitution should never be president fo the United States". Pence: I will have more to say about the government’s case after reviewing the indictment. The former president is entitled to the presumption of innocence but with this indictment, his candidacy means more talk about January 6th and more distractions. Our country is more important than one man. Our constitution is more important than any one man’s career. On January 6th, Former President Trump demanded that I choose between him and the Constitution. I chose the Constitution and I always will.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mike Pence: 'Our country is more important than one man'

children.content: Taking to social media, the former vice-president said the indictment "serves as an important reminder [that] anyone who puts himself over the Constitution should never be president fo the United States".
Pence:
I will have more to say about the government’s case after reviewing the indictment.
The former president is entitled to the presumption of innocence but with this indictment, his candidacy means more talk about January 6th and more distractions.
Our country is more important than one man. Our constitution is more important than any one man’s career.
On January 6th, Former President Trump demanded that I choose between him and the Constitution. I chose the Constitution and I always will.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC's North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan has more: Jade: There’s a familiar pattern to the way Donald Trump has responded to the three criminal cases brought against him. The former president once again broke the news of his impending indictment himself on his social media platform, Truth Social. He followed up that post with a statement accusing federal prosecutors of trying to interfere in next year’s presidential race, in which he’s still considered the leading candidate for the Republican nomination. And just like in the other two cases, his team immediately started appealing to supporters for donations. “What better way to show that YOU stood by the President’s side through *EVERY* phony indictment than your very own Limited-Edition “I STAND WITH TRUMP” T-Shirt, ” an email read. Donald Trump’s campaign says he’s raised millions of dollars since he was indicted in New York earlier this year, but reports suggest his legal fees have also put major pressure on his political action committee. Those costs will continue to mount, with the former president already facing the prospect of two criminal trials next year, and Jack Smith now pushing for a “speedy” resolution to the third.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Despite facing three criminal cases, Trump is still considered the leading Republican candidate

children.content: The ABC's North America bureau chief
Jade Macmillan
has more:
Jade:
There’s a familiar pattern to the way Donald Trump has responded to the three criminal cases brought against him.
The former president once again broke the news of his impending indictment himself on his social media platform, Truth Social.

He followed up that post with a statement accusing federal prosecutors of trying to interfere in next year’s presidential race, in which he’s still considered the leading candidate for the Republican nomination.
And just like in the other two cases, his team immediately started appealing to supporters for donations.
“What better way to show that YOU stood by the President’s side through *EVERY* phony indictment than your very own Limited-Edition “I STAND WITH TRUMP” T-Shirt,
” an email read.

Donald Trump’s campaign says he’s raised millions of dollars since he was indicted in New York earlier this year, but reports suggest his legal fees have also put major pressure on his political action committee.
Those costs will continue to mount, with the former president already facing the prospect of two criminal trials next year, and Jack Smith now pushing for a “speedy” resolution to the third.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has given back yesterday's gains and then some. Investors are worried about data showing the manufacturing industry contracting around the world including in China. The ASX 200 is down 0.8 per cent, although CommSec points out is just 3 per cent from its record high. Most sectors are in the red with utilities leading the losses after AGL Energy was sold off on a stockbroker downgrade. Real estate firms, financial stocks and miners are also weighing on the market. Top movers on ASX 200: BrainChip: +4% Pro Medicus: +2.6% Domino's Pizza: +2.1% Regis Resources: -4.3% AGL Energy: -4.1% Champion Iron: -3.6%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red at midday

children.content: The Australian share market has given back yesterday's gains and then some.
Investors are worried about data showing the manufacturing industry contracting around the world including in China.
The ASX 200 is down 0.8 per cent, although CommSec points out is just 3 per cent from its record high.
Most sectors are in the red with utilities leading the losses after AGL Energy was sold off on a stockbroker downgrade.
Real estate firms, financial stocks and miners are also weighing on the market.
Top movers on ASX 200:
BrainChip: +4%
Pro Medicus: +2.6%
Domino's Pizza: +2.1%
Regis Resources: -4.3%
AGL Energy: -4.1%
Champion Iron: -3.6%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand's unemployment rate climbed to a two year high over the June quarter amid a rise in the number of people looking for work. While the labour market is tight, the jobless rate rose from 3.4 per cent to 3.6 per cent seasonally adjusted with 109,000 people out of work according to Statistics New Zealand. It says the labour force participation rate of 72.4 per cent and the employment rate of 69.8 per cent are the highest on record. The tourism industry drove the increase with employment returning to pre-COVID levels. Wages increased by 4.3 per cent over the year to June. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to leave official interest rates unchanged at 5.5 per cent this month. The country's economy is in recession which was triggered by the central bank's aggressive rate rise campaign. While New Zealand's jobless rate is at a two year high, Australia's unemployment rate of 3.5 per cent, is near a fifty year low. New Zealand closed its borders from early 2020 to mid 2022 because of COVID-19, which drove down the unemployment rate because temporary migration was restricted.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Zealand unemployment rate at two year high

children.content: New Zealand's unemployment rate climbed to a two year high over the June quarter amid a rise in the number of people looking for work.
While the labour market is tight, the jobless rate rose from 3.4 per cent to 3.6 per cent seasonally adjusted with 109,000 people out of work according to Statistics New Zealand.

props.alt: Graph showing the NZ jobless rate

children.content: NZ jobless rate
(Statistics New Zealand )
It says the labour force participation rate of 72.4 per cent and the employment rate of 69.8 per cent are the highest on record.
The tourism industry drove the increase with employment returning to pre-COVID levels.
Wages increased by 4.3 per cent over the year to June.
The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to leave official interest rates unchanged at 5.5 per cent this month.
The country's economy is in recession which was triggered by the central bank's aggressive rate rise campaign.
While New Zealand's jobless rate is at a two year high, Australia's unemployment rate of 3.5 per cent, is near a fifty year low.
New Zealand closed its borders from early 2020 to mid 2022 because of COVID-19, which drove down the unemployment rate because temporary migration was restricted.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ride share firm Uber has swung from loss to profit for the second quarter of the financial year. Uber made a net profit of $US394 million ($596 million) from a net loss of $US2.6 billion ($3.9 billion) from the same quarter last year. Profit was boosted as its share market investments were revalued higher. Gross bookings rose by 16 per cent over the year to $US33.6 billion. About 25 million trips were made on the platform a day on average from April to June as travel recovered from the pandemic. Uber chief executive Dana Khoswoshahi said the company saw its first quarterly operating profit and its first quarter of free cash flow of more than $US1 billion. He says Uber is looking at further expanding into the travel market with flight, train and coach bookings available on its app. Mr Khoswoshahi says Uber is the rideshare leader in the majority of its international markets hitting record highs in Australia and Japan. However, its shares fell 5.7 per cent because its revenue of $US9.2 billion wasn't as good as expected by analysts.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Uber makes second quarter profit

children.content: Ride share firm Uber has swung from loss to profit for the second quarter of the financial year.
Uber made a net profit of $US394 million ($596 million) from a net loss of $US2.6 billion ($3.9 billion) from the same quarter last year.
Profit was boosted as its share market investments were revalued higher.
Gross bookings rose by 16 per cent over the year to $US33.6 billion.
About 25 million trips were made on the platform a day on average from April to June as travel recovered from the pandemic.
Uber chief executive Dana Khoswoshahi said the company saw its first quarterly operating profit and its first quarter of free cash flow of more than $US1 billion.
He says Uber is looking at further expanding into the travel market with flight, train and coach bookings available on its app.
Mr Khoswoshahi says Uber is the rideshare leader in the majority of its international markets hitting record highs in Australia and Japan.
However, its shares fell 5.7 per cent because its revenue of $US9.2 billion wasn't as good as expected by analysts.
